pull_request.title: Add global ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField to reverse stack and error order
pull_request.body:
Stacktrace is enabled, and the output gets like this:

```
{"level":"error","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"error":"seems we have an error here","time":1609086683}
```

`"stack"` is often long and `"error"` comes to the later part of the log line.
I have difficulties for this behavior when using with datadog (https://www.datadoghq.com/): datadog sends error logs to monitoring devices (like mobile phone), but those logs are truncated with the beginning part of logs. Those logs are filled with stacktrace and I cannot see the most important "error" field there.

This pull request introduces `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField`.
Setting `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField = true` results log output like this:
```
{"level":"error","error":"seems we have an error here","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"time":1609086683}
```
You can find the error message easily.

issue.title: Feature Request: Session Support
issue.body:
`curl` allows users to support cookie based sessions with the `--cookie-jar` and `--cookie` flags.

`httpie` has similar functionality with the `--session` flag.

Are there any plans to add similar functionality with `curlie`?

If there is already a way to do this (since `curlie` is a wrapper around `curl`), I'm not seeing a way to do this in the docs.

comment.body: Just pass it, there is nothing special to do.

commits.message: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext (#499)

issue.title: Invalid condition in WithContext method.
issue.body:
Since non-pointer receivers are passed **_by value_**, once the receiver for `WithContext` was reverted to a non-pointer, [this condition](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/89617ff99b2feb29ab2d8b6258fac9d671073792/ctx.go#L30) is guaranteed to always be false.

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

pull_request.title: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext
pull_request.body:
This change updates `WithContext` to better match documented behavior and also updates the documentation to both clarify existing behavior as well as the behavior expected by existing tests.

Note: since `WithContext` no longer employs a pointer receiver, the value comparison against the Context's attached logger value must be done via `reflect.DeepEqual`.

Fixes: #498

commits.message:
ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator (#497)

Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone
indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in
ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback
TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add
the TZ difference to UTC twice.

pull_request.title: ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator
pull_request.body:
Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add the TZ difference to UTC twice.

issue.title: The time value is wrong when outputting the log to console.
issue.body:
**Code**：

```
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
	"time"

	"github.com/rs/zerolog"
	"github.com/rs/zerolog/log"
)

func main() {
	timeFormat := "2006-01-02 15:04:05"

	t := time.Now()
	fmt.Print("local zone: ")
	fmt.Println(t.Local().Zone())
	fmt.Println("def:", t.Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("loc:", t.Local().Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("utc:", t.UTC().Format(timeFormat))

	zerolog.TimeFieldFormat = timeFormat
	log.Print("hello world")

	log.Logger = log.Output(zerolog.ConsoleWriter{Out: os.Stderr, TimeFormat: timeFormat})
	log.Info().Msg("Wrong time")
}
```


**Output**:

> local zone: CST 28800
> def: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> loc: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> utc: 2022-09-23 13:19:29
> {"level":"debug","time":"2022-09-23 21:19:29","message":"hello world"}
> **2022-09-24 05:19:29** INF Wrong time

The local time is **2022-09-23 21:19:29** and the UTC time is **2022-09-23 13:19:29**, but the console output time is **2022-09-24 05:19:29** .
This issue is caused by #415 .

comment.body: I'm fine with a local tz default on console writer.

commits.message:
Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object (#437)

Co-authored-by: Mario Cormier <mcormier@rossvideo.com>

pull_request.title: Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object
pull_request.body:
I found myself wanting to log the type of an object and was convinced there would be a method to do that already, but I didn't find one.  Here's a case where one might want such a method:

```go
	var value interface{}
	var result string
	switch v := value.(type) {
	case int:
		result = strconv.Itoa(v)
	case string:
		result = v
	default:
		log.Panic().Type("type", v).Msg("Unexpected value type")
	}
	log.Info().Msg(result)
```

Let me know if there's anything else that needs to change for this to get accepted.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

As you can see in the attached log, many times a day it fails. The number of tries listed shows how many loops required before nextdns reports "running" 

Other users are seeing similar things as covered in [this forum post](https://help.nextdns.io/t/g9h78dq/lot-of-disconnections-nextdns-cli-has-to-be-reinstalled-every-2-days). 

[nextdns.log](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/files/9671612/nextdns.log)

comment.body: What do you get in `journalctl -ef` while this happen?

issue.title: `nextdns config list` didn't exactly match the running config, when using config file
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.10
 - Platform: Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS with kernel 5.4.0-105-generic

**Problem:** NextDNS cli client didn't show the config file as expected. The config ID and other configs are specified in the config file, but `nextdns config list` didn't see it.

The NextDNS client was installed via the Debian Based Distribution Manual Install method mentioned on wiki: 
- https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/Debian-Based-Distribution#manual-install


The NextDNS service was installed by the command:

```sh
sudo nextdns install -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```


The content of `/opt/nextdns/config` is actually the result from a previous config, dump via the command `sudo nextdns config list`(the config ID was replaced by `xxxxxx`):
```
discovery-dns 
max-inflight-requests 512
auto-activate false
mdns all
detect-captive-portals false
bogus-priv true
use-hosts false
timeout 5s
listen localhost:53
log-queries false
report-client-info true
hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
```

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns
After=network.target
Before=nss-lookup.target
Wants=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
StartLimitInterval=5
StartLimitBurst=10
Environment=SERVICE_RUN_MODE=1
ExecStart=/usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
RestartSec=120
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
```sh
$ ps aux | grep root | grep nextdns
root      543523  0.0  0.6 711800 12712 ?        Ssl  13:49   0:01 /usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```

But when I run: `sudo nextdns config list` to see the config, the `cache-size` didn't show up, `max-inflight-requests` and `report-client-info` is different:

```
discovery-dns 
use-hosts true
listen localhost:53
config /opt/nextdns/config
log-queries false
cache-size 0
cache-max-age 0s
setup-router false
timeout 5s
max-ttl 0s
report-client-info false
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
auto-activate false
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
detect-captive-portals false
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv true
```

It's a little bit odd that the displayed config doesn't match the running config. Looks like NextDNS client maintained another config file, and then let the specified config file to overwrite it? Could be messy when debugging, because you need to check two places for the configs and consider the overwrite by yoruself.

comment.body: That would be welcomed, thanks for proposing.

hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
```

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns
After=network.target
Before=nss-lookup.target
Wants=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
StartLimitInterval=5
StartLimitBurst=10
Environment=SERVICE_RUN_MODE=1
ExecStart=/usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
RestartSec=120
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
```sh
$ ps aux | grep root | grep nextdns
root      543523  0.0  0.6 711800 12712 ?        Ssl  13:49   0:01 /usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```

But when I run: `sudo nextdns config list` to see the config, the `cache-size` didn't show up, `max-inflight-requests` and `report-client-info` is different:

```
discovery-dns 
use-hosts true
listen localhost:53
config /opt/nextdns/config
log-queries false
cache-size 0
cache-max-age 0s
setup-router false
timeout 5s
max-ttl 0s
report-client-info false
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
auto-activate false
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
detect-captive-portals false
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv true
```

It's a little bit odd that the displayed config doesn't match the running config. Looks like NextDNS client maintained another config file, and then let the specified config file to overwrite it? Could be messy when debugging, because you need to check two places for the configs and consider the overwrite by yoruself.

comment.body: You are installing with a custom configuration path parameter (`-config`) but then reading the default path (by not providing the same `-config` parameter). I hope it make sense.

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

comment.body:
Thank-you for your feedback. This repository is related to the CLI client and this feature request is about the service in general. General product ideas should be directed to our community forum https://help.nextdns.io. I'm going to close this issue here, feel free to create a new topic on our forum.

As a quick answer, your idea makes sense but we are purposely not adding such capability to keep the product experience simple. Creating different configuration is the way to apply different policies to different devices.

issue.title: [Feature Request] Prom Annotations: add dynamic step to show many annotations as a range

labels.name: prio/low
labels.description: It's a good idea, but not scheduled for any release

issue.body:
A response to https://github.com/grafana/support-escalations/issues/3120
**Scope:** Prometheus annotations
**Impact:** Users who create annotations for ranges and zoom in and out of panels
**Why now?** This is a visual feature. The feature will help users who do not wish to change the min step of annotations every time the zoom on a panel.

Description: Add a dynamic min step option in creating Prometheus annotation.

We want to show annotations in a range and not have them broken down into individual elements when changing the panel size by zooming out. When an annotation returns multiple events, Prometheus can either return a range of events or each individual event. 

Expected Result:
![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228236-2979b597-991b-452c-896f-09577bf2f14c.png)

Undesired:
![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228255-f932d740-cdab-4c02-8b37-bfcff127f0a5.png)

This is dependent on the min step chosen by the person who created the annotation. 

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228369-78c5c11e-f595-4959-b9c6-1a52680e3ed8.png)

We compare the last event + the step to the next event's timestamp to either show the range or the many elements
https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/1e06b0170b3145ffd53b5fcb0d16d710c6bfc42f/public/app/plugins/datasource/prometheus/datasource.tsx#L808-L812

Acceptance Criteria: Show the range of annotations when a user chooses the dynamic min step.

Things to consider: 
It is not suggested to use this feature when creating annotations for the purpose of alerting
https://github.com/grafana/support-escalations/issues/2019#

comment.body: I don't think it is practical. Whatever value you use, you will either get the issue with larger window or will lose granularity with smaller windows.

issue.title: (#470) Localize github.com/pkg/errors
issue.body:
# Motivation
[Issue](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/issues/470) #470 reported by @skormos

# Changes
Adds new internal package `errors` with test coverage.

# Summary
Localizes following functions (and required types and methods) from [github.com/pkg/errors](https://github.com/pkg/errors) as it is no longer being maintained.
```go
New(message string) error
Wrap(err error, message string) error
```
# Related Issues
Closes #470
Helps in #462

comment.body: Reading the change I'm not really fan of the resulting API. I wonder if we could keep backward compat (when getting a wrapped error) and at the same time, auto-wrap an error when Stack is present and Err is called. This way we do not expose a new API.

issue.title: Debian: no armhf .deb file found
issue.body:
This started showing up yesterday (possibly earlier).

```
root@docker:/# apt search nextdns
Sorting... Done
Full Text Search... Done
nextdns/stable 1.37.4 armel
  NextDNS DNS/53 to DoH Proxy

root@docker:/# apt install nextdns
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree... Done
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package nextdns
```

This is inside a Docker container running Debian testing on a Raspberry Pi 

```
root@docker:/# cat /etc/os-release
PRETTY_NAME="Debian GNU/Linux bookworm/sid"
NAME="Debian GNU/Linux"
ID=debian
HOME_URL="https://www.debian.org/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://www.debian.org/support"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.debian.org/"
```

The sources are properly added

```
root@docker:/# cat /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nextdns.list
deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/nextdns.gpg] https://repo.nextdns.io/deb stable main
```

Running the install script gives the same error (nextdns not found).

It looks like searching for nextdns returns the `armel` version, but not the `armhf` version. This is also true outside of a docker container (ie on the host). 

```
liana ~ # apt search nextdns
Sorting... Done
Full Text Search... Done
nextdns/stable 1.37.4 armel
  NextDNS DNS/53 to DoH Proxy
liana ~ # uname -a
Linux liana 5.10.63-v7l+ #1459 SMP Wed Oct 6 16:41:57 BST 2021 armv7l GNU/Linux
```

issue.title: Must manually input iptables rules on UDMP (UniFi Dream Machine Pro)
issue.body:
## Context
 - CLI Version: nextdns version 1.37.11
 - IPv4 and IPv6 native (via Prefix Delegation and RA)
 - Platform:  UDM Pro
 ```
Device information summary:
    Subsystem ID: ea15
    Family: UniFi Dream Machine (UDM)
    Model: UniFi Dream Machine Pro (UDM-Pro)
    Firmware: 1.12.22 (1.12.22)
```
### Expected
Installing on UbiOS should automatically start routing DNS to NextDNS over DoH

### Actual
nextdns service was started and running, but DNS resolution was going to my ISP instead

## Debug Steps
I installed NextDNS via the UniFi [NextDNS wiki](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/UnifiOS) without any errors. Once installed, the service said it was installed and `nextdns status` showed `running` - `nextdns log` had no errors


When viewing [my.nextdns.io](https://my.nextdns.io) I noticed the status showed red and then sometimes went green as configured properly. When viewing logs, no traffic was coming through regularly, however. I verified my dns server handed out by DHCP pointed to my UDM / router. When it went red, it was showing that it was using my ISP's NS which was a little fishy since only the UDM should be using that... After reviewing the go setup code for ubi (https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/blob/master/router/ubios/setup.go#L97-L118) I saw iptables were used to reroute DNS traffic over to nextdns so I went to verify this. Surprisingly, nothing was there except the ipv4 chain... so I restarted the service, and there still were no rules. I then proceeded to create the ipv4 rules, ipv6 chain, and ipv6 rules manually over ssh. 


After setting these rules, it instantly worked on all of my devices leading me to believe there is something funky going on in the go code.

## Workaround
Manually running the following commands on the UDM / Gateway
```
iptables -t nat -N NEXTDNS
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING 1 -m addrtype --dst-type LOCAL -j NEXTDNS
iptables -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p udp -m udp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination 127.0.0.1:5553
iptables -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p tcp -m tcp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination 127.0.0.1:5553
# if using IPv6 run the following too
ip6tables -t nat -N NEXTDNS
ip6tables -t nat -I PREROUTING 1 -m set --match-set UBIOS6ADDRv6_br0 dst -j NEXTDNS
ip6tables  -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p udp -m udp --dport 53 -j REDIRECT --to-port 5553
ip6tables  -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p tcp -m tcp --dport 53 -j REDIRECT --to-port 5553
```


I also could get NextDNS resolution working if I changed the WAN DNS settings in the control panel to use the given IPs in the NextDNS setup, but this would not run through DoH. This is how I got my UniFi gear to resolve through NextDNS though, as they wouldn't happily use the gateway's proxy.

comment.body: Do you have any idea why the iptables for IPv6 are disappearing? Are they added then removed or not added at all?

issue.title: Fatal() does os.Exit(1) when log is disabled
issue.body:
I think this is an error, It was discovered after upgrading from 1.26.1 to 1.28.0:

`Fatal()` here https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L367

calls `newEvent` https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L444

 with the `done` paremeter being `os.Exit(1)` so here even the log is disabled, `done` is executed which was not like this before:

https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L448

comment.body: If you call Fatal on a logger in your code, you are not supposed to know the logger is disabled, and the code logic is not supposed to pass the Fatal statement.

pull_request.title: Add global ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField to reverse stack and error order
pull_request.body:
Stacktrace is enabled, and the output gets like this:

```
{"level":"error","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"error":"seems we have an error here","time":1609086683}
```

`"stack"` is often long and `"error"` comes to the later part of the log line.
I have difficulties for this behavior when using with datadog (https://www.datadoghq.com/): datadog sends error logs to monitoring devices (like mobile phone), but those logs are truncated with the beginning part of logs. Those logs are filled with stacktrace and I cannot see the most important "error" field there.

This pull request introduces `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField`.
Setting `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField = true` results log output like this:
```
{"level":"error","error":"seems we have an error here","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"time":1609086683}
```
You can find the error message easily.

commits.message: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext (#499)

issue.title: Invalid condition in WithContext method.
issue.body:
Since non-pointer receivers are passed **_by value_**, once the receiver for `WithContext` was reverted to a non-pointer, [this condition](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/89617ff99b2feb29ab2d8b6258fac9d671073792/ctx.go#L30) is guaranteed to always be false.

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

pull_request.title: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext
pull_request.body:
This change updates `WithContext` to better match documented behavior and also updates the documentation to both clarify existing behavior as well as the behavior expected by existing tests.

Note: since `WithContext` no longer employs a pointer receiver, the value comparison against the Context's attached logger value must be done via `reflect.DeepEqual`.

Fixes: #498

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

commits.message:
ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator (#497)

Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone
indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in
ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback
TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add
the TZ difference to UTC twice.

pull_request.title: ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add the TZ difference to UTC twice.

issue.title: Invalid condition in WithContext method.
issue.body:
Since non-pointer receivers are passed **_by value_**, once the receiver for `WithContext` was reverted to a non-pointer, [this condition](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/89617ff99b2feb29ab2d8b6258fac9d671073792/ctx.go#L30) is guaranteed to always be false.

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

comment.body: This is a regression from this commit: https://github.com/rs/zerolog/commit/588a61c2df4bf7b92e12b826b226059b9f262190

issue.title: The time value is wrong when outputting the log to console.
issue.body:
**Code**：

```
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
	"time"

	"github.com/rs/zerolog"
	"github.com/rs/zerolog/log"
)

func main() {
	timeFormat := "2006-01-02 15:04:05"

	t := time.Now()
	fmt.Print("local zone: ")
	fmt.Println(t.Local().Zone())
	fmt.Println("def:", t.Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("loc:", t.Local().Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("utc:", t.UTC().Format(timeFormat))

	zerolog.TimeFieldFormat = timeFormat
	log.Print("hello world")

	log.Logger = log.Output(zerolog.ConsoleWriter{Out: os.Stderr, TimeFormat: timeFormat})
	log.Info().Msg("Wrong time")
}
```


**Output**:

> local zone: CST 28800
> def: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> loc: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> utc: 2022-09-23 13:19:29
> {"level":"debug","time":"2022-09-23 21:19:29","message":"hello world"}
> **2022-09-24 05:19:29** INF Wrong time

The local time is **2022-09-23 21:19:29** and the UTC time is **2022-09-23 13:19:29**, but the console output time is **2022-09-24 05:19:29** .
This issue is caused by #415 .

comment.body: I'm fine with a local tz default on console writer.

pull_request.title: Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object
pull_request.body:
I found myself wanting to log the type of an object and was convinced there would be a method to do that already, but I didn't find one.  Here's a case where one might want such a method:

```go
	var value interface{}
	var result string
	switch v := value.(type) {
	case int:
		result = strconv.Itoa(v)
	case string:
		result = v
	default:
		log.Panic().Type("type", v).Msg("Unexpected value type")
	}
	log.Info().Msg(result)
```

Let me know if there's anything else that needs to change for this to get accepted.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

As you can see in the attached log, many times a day it fails. The number of tries listed shows how many loops required before nextdns reports "running" 

Other users are seeing similar things as covered in [this forum post](https://help.nextdns.io/t/g9h78dq/lot-of-disconnections-nextdns-cli-has-to-be-reinstalled-every-2-days). 

[nextdns.log](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/files/9671612/nextdns.log)

comment.body: What do you get in `journalctl -ef` while this happen?

comment.body: From those logs we can only see that systemd is the one stopping and restarting the nextdns server. It is hard to tell from there what is making systemd doing that. Could be some maintenance cronjobs from firewalla, but I don't see why something would do that. More complete systemd logs could help understand what is going one perhaps.

issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.10
 - Platform: Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS with kernel 5.4.0-105-generic

**Problem:** NextDNS cli client didn't show the config file as expected. The config ID and other configs are specified in the config file, but `nextdns config list` didn't see it.

The NextDNS client was installed via the Debian Based Distribution Manual Install method mentioned on wiki: 
- https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/Debian-Based-Distribution#manual-install


The NextDNS service was installed by the command:

```sh
sudo nextdns install -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```


The content of `/opt/nextdns/config` is actually the result from a previous config, dump via the command `sudo nextdns config list`(the config ID was replaced by `xxxxxx`):
```
discovery-dns 
max-inflight-requests 512
auto-activate false
mdns all
detect-captive-portals false
bogus-priv true
use-hosts false
timeout 5s
listen localhost:53
log-queries false
report-client-info true
hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
```

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns
After=network.target
Before=nss-lookup.target
Wants=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
StartLimitInterval=5
StartLimitBurst=10
Environment=SERVICE_RUN_MODE=1
ExecStart=/usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
RestartSec=120
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
```sh
$ ps aux | grep root | grep nextdns
root      543523  0.0  0.6 711800 12712 ?        Ssl  13:49   0:01 /usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```

But when I run: `sudo nextdns config list` to see the config, the `cache-size` didn't show up, `max-inflight-requests` and `report-client-info` is different:

```
discovery-dns 
use-hosts true
listen localhost:53
config /opt/nextdns/config
log-queries false
cache-size 0
cache-max-age 0s
setup-router false
timeout 5s
max-ttl 0s
report-client-info false
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
auto-activate false
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
detect-captive-portals false
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv true
```

It's a little bit odd that the displayed config doesn't match the running config. Looks like NextDNS client maintained another config file, and then let the specified config file to overwrite it? Could be messy when debugging, because you need to check two places for the configs and consider the overwrite by yoruself.

comment.body: That would be welcomed, thanks for proposing.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

As you can see in the attached log, many times a day it fails. The number of tries listed shows how many loops required before nextdns reports "running" 

Other users are seeing similar things as covered in [this forum post](https://help.nextdns.io/t/g9h78dq/lot-of-disconnections-nextdns-cli-has-to-be-reinstalled-every-2-days). 

[nextdns.log](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/files/9671612/nextdns.log)

comment.body: Do you get an error in the logs when the service exists this way?

Sorry I got confused between --config and --config-file. In your case the install is probably editing an existing config, so you get a merge of your --configs with you added previously. Would that make sense?

My advise would be to use `sudo nextdns config edit` and make sure you only keep the lines you want.

Does it make sense?

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

comment.body:
Thank-you for your feedback. This repository is related to the CLI client and this feature request is about the service in general. General product ideas should be directed to our community forum https://help.nextdns.io. I'm going to close this issue here, feel free to create a new topic on our forum.

As a quick answer, your idea makes sense but we are purposely not adding such capability to keep the product experience simple. Creating different configuration is the way to apply different policies to different devices.

issue.title: [Feature Request] Prom Annotations: add dynamic step to show many annotations as a range

labels.name: prio/low
labels.description: It's a good idea, but not scheduled for any release

issue.body:
A response to https://github.com/grafana/support-escalations/issues/3120
**Scope:** Prometheus annotations
**Impact:** Users who create annotations for ranges and zoom in and out of panels
**Why now?** This is a visual feature. The feature will help users who do not wish to change the min step of annotations every time the zoom on a panel.

Description: Add a dynamic min step option in creating Prometheus annotation.

We want to show annotations in a range and not have them broken down into individual elements when changing the panel size by zooming out. When an annotation returns multiple events, Prometheus can either return a range of events or each individual event. 

Expected Result:
![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228236-2979b597-991b-452c-896f-09577bf2f14c.png)

Undesired:
![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228255-f932d740-cdab-4c02-8b37-bfcff127f0a5.png)

This is dependent on the min step chosen by the person who created the annotation. 

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228369-78c5c11e-f595-4959-b9c6-1a52680e3ed8.png)

We compare the last event + the step to the next event's timestamp to either show the range or the many elements
https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/1e06b0170b3145ffd53b5fcb0d16d710c6bfc42f/public/app/plugins/datasource/prometheus/datasource.tsx#L808-L812

Acceptance Criteria: Show the range of annotations when a user chooses the dynamic min step.

Things to consider: 
It is not suggested to use this feature when creating annotations for the purpose of alerting
https://github.com/grafana/support-escalations/issues/2019#

comment.body: I don't think it is practical. Whatever value you use, you will either get the issue with larger window or will lose granularity with smaller windows.

Adding a first draft on building an MSI using Advanced Installer, can handle the properties PROFILE/ ARP/ UI.

The saving of the properties was moved outside of the aip project so that it can be move easily updated, it is located in the powershell script called InstallProperties.ps1

pull_request.body:
In about 5% of instances of

    go test -count 100000 -run TestClose -timeout 30s .

the test ends in a deadlock:

    panic: test timed out after 30s

    goroutine 6465 [running]:
    testing.(*M).startAlarm.func1()
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:2029 +0x8e
    created by time.goFunc
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/time/sleep.go:176 +0x32

    goroutine 1 [chan receive]:
    testing.(*T).Run(0xc000636000, {0x54a7e4?, 0x4bba45?}, 0x555b78)
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:1487 +0x37a
    testing.runTests.func1(0xc000636000?)
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:1839 +0x6e
    testing.tRunner(0xc000636000, 0xc000069cd8)
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:1439 +0x102
    testing.runTests(0xc0000a63c0?, {0x63b0e0, 0x2, 0x2}, {0x7fb6ff136108?, 0x40?, 0x643c00?})
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:1837 +0x457
    testing.(*M).Run(0xc0000a63c0)
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:1719 +0x5d9
    main.main()
            _testmain.go:55 +0x1aa

    goroutine 27226 [sync.Cond.Wait]:
    sync.runtime_notifyListWait(0xc00063a090, 0x0)
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/runtime/sema.go:513 +0x13d
    sync.(*Cond).Wait(0xc00063a080?)
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/sync/cond.go:56 +0x8c
    github.com/rs/zerolog/diode/internal/diodes.(*Waiter).Next(0xc0004ee090)
            /home/ddn/w/zerolog/diode/internal/diodes/waiter.go:69 +0x9b
    github.com/rs/zerolog/diode.Writer.poll({{0x57a600, 0xc0004ee060}, {0x57ae68, 0xc0004ee090}, 0xc000626040, 0xc000602120})
            /home/ddn/w/zerolog/diode/diode.go:96 +0x83
    created by github.com/rs/zerolog/diode.NewWriter
            /home/ddn/w/zerolog/diode/diode.go:70 +0x36f

    goroutine 27224 [chan receive]:
    github.com/rs/zerolog/diode.Writer.Close({{0x57a600, 0xc0004ee060}, {0x57ae68, 0xc0004ee090}, 0xc000626040, 0xc000602120})
            /home/ddn/w/zerolog/diode/diode.go:86 +0x4a
    github.com/rs/zerolog/diode_test.TestClose(0xc0006e6a00?)
            /home/ddn/w/zerolog/diode/diode_test.go:38 +0x1eb
    testing.tRunner(0xc0006361a0, 0x555b78)
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:1439 +0x102
    created by testing.(*T).Run
            /home/ddn/.conda/envs/katana-dev/go/src/testing/testing.go:1486 +0x35f

issue.title: (#470) Localize github.com/pkg/errors
issue.body:
# Motivation
[Issue](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/issues/470) #470 reported by @skormos

# Changes
Adds new internal package `errors` with test coverage.

# Summary
Localizes following functions (and required types and methods) from [github.com/pkg/errors](https://github.com/pkg/errors) as it is no longer being maintained.
```go
New(message string) error
Wrap(err error, message string) error
```
# Related Issues
Closes #470
Helps in #462

comment.body: Reading the change I'm not really fan of the resulting API. I wonder if we could keep backward compat (when getting a wrapped error) and at the same time, auto-wrap an error when Stack is present and Err is called. This way we do not expose a new API.

issue.body:
This started showing up yesterday (possibly earlier).

```
root@docker:/# apt search nextdns
Sorting... Done
Full Text Search... Done
nextdns/stable 1.37.4 armel
  NextDNS DNS/53 to DoH Proxy

root@docker:/# apt install nextdns
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree... Done
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package nextdns
```

This is inside a Docker container running Debian testing on a Raspberry Pi 

```
root@docker:/# cat /etc/os-release
PRETTY_NAME="Debian GNU/Linux bookworm/sid"
NAME="Debian GNU/Linux"
ID=debian
HOME_URL="https://www.debian.org/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://www.debian.org/support"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.debian.org/"
```

The sources are properly added

```
root@docker:/# cat /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nextdns.list
deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/nextdns.gpg] https://repo.nextdns.io/deb stable main
```

Running the install script gives the same error (nextdns not found).

It looks like searching for nextdns returns the `armel` version, but not the `armhf` version. This is also true outside of a docker container (ie on the host). 

```
liana ~ # apt search nextdns
Sorting... Done
Full Text Search... Done
nextdns/stable 1.37.4 armel
  NextDNS DNS/53 to DoH Proxy
liana ~ # uname -a
Linux liana 5.10.63-v7l+ #1459 SMP Wed Oct 6 16:41:57 BST 2021 armv7l GNU/Linux
```

issue.title: Must manually input iptables rules on UDMP (UniFi Dream Machine Pro)
issue.body:
## Context
 - CLI Version: nextdns version 1.37.11
 - IPv4 and IPv6 native (via Prefix Delegation and RA)
 - Platform:  UDM Pro
 ```
Device information summary:
    Subsystem ID: ea15
    Family: UniFi Dream Machine (UDM)
    Model: UniFi Dream Machine Pro (UDM-Pro)
    Firmware: 1.12.22 (1.12.22)
```
### Expected
Installing on UbiOS should automatically start routing DNS to NextDNS over DoH

### Actual
nextdns service was started and running, but DNS resolution was going to my ISP instead

## Debug Steps
I installed NextDNS via the UniFi [NextDNS wiki](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/UnifiOS) without any errors. Once installed, the service said it was installed and `nextdns status` showed `running` - `nextdns log` had no errors


When viewing [my.nextdns.io](https://my.nextdns.io) I noticed the status showed red and then sometimes went green as configured properly. When viewing logs, no traffic was coming through regularly, however. I verified my dns server handed out by DHCP pointed to my UDM / router. When it went red, it was showing that it was using my ISP's NS which was a little fishy since only the UDM should be using that... After reviewing the go setup code for ubi (https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/blob/master/router/ubios/setup.go#L97-L118) I saw iptables were used to reroute DNS traffic over to nextdns so I went to verify this. Surprisingly, nothing was there except the ipv4 chain... so I restarted the service, and there still were no rules. I then proceeded to create the ipv4 rules, ipv6 chain, and ipv6 rules manually over ssh. 


After setting these rules, it instantly worked on all of my devices leading me to believe there is something funky going on in the go code.

## Workaround
Manually running the following commands on the UDM / Gateway
```
iptables -t nat -N NEXTDNS
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING 1 -m addrtype --dst-type LOCAL -j NEXTDNS
iptables -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p udp -m udp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination 127.0.0.1:5553
iptables -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p tcp -m tcp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination 127.0.0.1:5553
# if using IPv6 run the following too
ip6tables -t nat -N NEXTDNS
ip6tables -t nat -I PREROUTING 1 -m set --match-set UBIOS6ADDRv6_br0 dst -j NEXTDNS
ip6tables  -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p udp -m udp --dport 53 -j REDIRECT --to-port 5553
ip6tables  -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p tcp -m tcp --dport 53 -j REDIRECT --to-port 5553
```


I also could get NextDNS resolution working if I changed the WAN DNS settings in the control panel to use the given IPs in the NextDNS setup, but this would not run through DoH. This is how I got my UniFi gear to resolve through NextDNS though, as they wouldn't happily use the gateway's proxy.

comment.body: Do you have any idea why the iptables for IPv6 are disappearing? Are they added then removed or not added at all?

issue.title: Fatal() does os.Exit(1) when log is disabled
issue.body:
I think this is an error, It was discovered after upgrading from 1.26.1 to 1.28.0:

`Fatal()` here https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L367

calls `newEvent` https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L444

 with the `done` paremeter being `os.Exit(1)` so here even the log is disabled, `done` is executed which was not like this before:

https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L448

comment.body: If you call Fatal on a logger in your code, you are not supposed to know the logger is disabled, and the code logic is not supposed to pass the Fatal statement.

`Fatal()` here https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L367

calls `newEvent` https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L444

 with the `done` paremeter being `os.Exit(1)` so here even the log is disabled, `done` is executed which was not like this before:

pull_request.title: Add global ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField to reverse stack and error order
pull_request.body:
Stacktrace is enabled, and the output gets like this:

```
{"level":"error","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"error":"seems we have an error here","time":1609086683}
```

`"stack"` is often long and `"error"` comes to the later part of the log line.
I have difficulties for this behavior when using with datadog (https://www.datadoghq.com/): datadog sends error logs to monitoring devices (like mobile phone), but those logs are truncated with the beginning part of logs. Those logs are filled with stacktrace and I cannot see the most important "error" field there.

This pull request introduces `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField`.
Setting `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField = true` results log output like this:
```
{"level":"error","error":"seems we have an error here","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"time":1609086683}
```
You can find the error message easily.

issue.title: UpdateContext data race
issue.body:
Hi,

I am getting data race for this implementation. All I need is to generate and add a request id to the logger so that each log entry has it by default. How do I solve this issue please? I am coming from logrus where I can do the same thing without a problem but if I cannot solve this issue I will have to go back which is what I prefer to avoid for different reasons.

Thanks

```go
type requestID string

const requestIDKey = requestID("request_id")

func RequestID(next http.Handler) http.Handler {
	return http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
		id := xid.New().String()

		log.Logger.UpdateContext(func(c zerolog.Context) zerolog.Context {
		 	return c.Str(string(requestIDKey), id)
		})

		w.Header().Set("X-Request-ID", id)

		next.ServeHTTP(w, r.WithContext(context.WithValue(r.Context(), requestIDKey, id)))

comment.body: Use `log.With().Str(requestIDKey), id).Logger()` instead.

commits.message: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext (#499)

issue.title: Invalid condition in WithContext method.
issue.body:
Since non-pointer receivers are passed **_by value_**, once the receiver for `WithContext` was reverted to a non-pointer, [this condition](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/89617ff99b2feb29ab2d8b6258fac9d671073792/ctx.go#L30) is guaranteed to always be false.

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

pull_request.title: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext
pull_request.body:
This change updates `WithContext` to better match documented behavior and also updates the documentation to both clarify existing behavior as well as the behavior expected by existing tests.

Note: since `WithContext` no longer employs a pointer receiver, the value comparison against the Context's attached logger value must be done via `reflect.DeepEqual`.

Fixes: #498

commits.message:
ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator (#497)

Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone
indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in
ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback
TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add
the TZ difference to UTC twice.

pull_request.title: ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator
pull_request.body:
Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add the TZ difference to UTC twice.

issue.title: The time value is wrong when outputting the log to console.
issue.body:
**Code**：

```
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
	"time"

	"github.com/rs/zerolog"
	"github.com/rs/zerolog/log"
)

func main() {
	timeFormat := "2006-01-02 15:04:05"

	t := time.Now()
	fmt.Print("local zone: ")
	fmt.Println(t.Local().Zone())
	fmt.Println("def:", t.Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("loc:", t.Local().Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("utc:", t.UTC().Format(timeFormat))

	zerolog.TimeFieldFormat = timeFormat
	log.Print("hello world")

	log.Logger = log.Output(zerolog.ConsoleWriter{Out: os.Stderr, TimeFormat: timeFormat})
	log.Info().Msg("Wrong time")
}
```


**Output**:

> local zone: CST 28800
> def: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> loc: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> utc: 2022-09-23 13:19:29
> {"level":"debug","time":"2022-09-23 21:19:29","message":"hello world"}
> **2022-09-24 05:19:29** INF Wrong time

The local time is **2022-09-23 21:19:29** and the UTC time is **2022-09-23 13:19:29**, but the console output time is **2022-09-24 05:19:29** .
This issue is caused by #415 .

comment.body: I'm fine with a local tz default on console writer.

commits.message:
Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object (#437)

Co-authored-by: Mario Cormier <mcormier@rossvideo.com>

pull_request.title: Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object
pull_request.body:
I found myself wanting to log the type of an object and was convinced there would be a method to do that already, but I didn't find one.  Here's a case where one might want such a method:

```go
	var value interface{}
	var result string
	switch v := value.(type) {
	case int:
		result = strconv.Itoa(v)
	case string:
		result = v
	default:
		log.Panic().Type("type", v).Msg("Unexpected value type")
	}
	log.Info().Msg(result)
```

Let me know if there's anything else that needs to change for this to get accepted.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

As you can see in the attached log, many times a day it fails. The number of tries listed shows how many loops required before nextdns reports "running" 

Other users are seeing similar things as covered in [this forum post](https://help.nextdns.io/t/g9h78dq/lot-of-disconnections-nextdns-cli-has-to-be-reinstalled-every-2-days). 

[nextdns.log](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/files/9671612/nextdns.log)

comment.body: What do you get in `journalctl -ef` while this happen?

issue.title: `nextdns config list` didn't exactly match the running config, when using config file
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.10
 - Platform: Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS with kernel 5.4.0-105-generic

**Problem:** NextDNS cli client didn't show the config file as expected. The config ID and other configs are specified in the config file, but `nextdns config list` didn't see it.

The NextDNS client was installed via the Debian Based Distribution Manual Install method mentioned on wiki: 
- https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/Debian-Based-Distribution#manual-install


The NextDNS service was installed by the command:

```sh
sudo nextdns install -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```


The content of `/opt/nextdns/config` is actually the result from a previous config, dump via the command `sudo nextdns config list`(the config ID was replaced by `xxxxxx`):
```
discovery-dns 
max-inflight-requests 512
auto-activate false
mdns all
detect-captive-portals false
bogus-priv true
use-hosts false
timeout 5s
listen localhost:53
log-queries false
report-client-info true
hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
```

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns
After=network.target
Before=nss-lookup.target
Wants=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
StartLimitInterval=5
StartLimitBurst=10
Environment=SERVICE_RUN_MODE=1
ExecStart=/usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
RestartSec=120
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
```sh
$ ps aux | grep root | grep nextdns
root      543523  0.0  0.6 711800 12712 ?        Ssl  13:49   0:01 /usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```

But when I run: `sudo nextdns config list` to see the config, the `cache-size` didn't show up, `max-inflight-requests` and `report-client-info` is different:

```
discovery-dns 
use-hosts true
listen localhost:53
config /opt/nextdns/config
log-queries false
cache-size 0
cache-max-age 0s
setup-router false
timeout 5s
max-ttl 0s
report-client-info false
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
auto-activate false
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
detect-captive-portals false
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv true
```

It's a little bit odd that the displayed config doesn't match the running config. Looks like NextDNS client maintained another config file, and then let the specified config file to overwrite it? Could be messy when debugging, because you need to check two places for the configs and consider the overwrite by yoruself.

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

comment.body:
Thank-you for your feedback. This repository is related to the CLI client and this feature request is about the service in general. General product ideas should be directed to our community forum https://help.nextdns.io. I'm going to close this issue here, feel free to create a new topic on our forum.

As a quick answer, your idea makes sense but we are purposely not adding such capability to keep the product experience simple. Creating different configuration is the way to apply different policies to different devices.

issue.title: [Feature Request] Prom Annotations: add dynamic step to show many annotations as a range

labels.name: prio/low
labels.description: It's a good idea, but not scheduled for any release

issue.body:
A response to https://github.com/grafana/support-escalations/issues/3120
**Scope:** Prometheus annotations
**Impact:** Users who create annotations for ranges and zoom in and out of panels
**Why now?** This is a visual feature. The feature will help users who do not wish to change the min step of annotations every time the zoom on a panel.

Description: Add a dynamic min step option in creating Prometheus annotation.

We want to show annotations in a range and not have them broken down into individual elements when changing the panel size by zooming out. When an annotation returns multiple events, Prometheus can either return a range of events or each individual event. 

Expected Result:
![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228236-2979b597-991b-452c-896f-09577bf2f14c.png)

Undesired:
![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228255-f932d740-cdab-4c02-8b37-bfcff127f0a5.png)

This is dependent on the min step chosen by the person who created the annotation. 

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25674746/190228369-78c5c11e-f595-4959-b9c6-1a52680e3ed8.png)

We compare the last event + the step to the next event's timestamp to either show the range or the many elements
https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/1e06b0170b3145ffd53b5fcb0d16d710c6bfc42f/public/app/plugins/datasource/prometheus/datasource.tsx#L808-L812

Acceptance Criteria: Show the range of annotations when a user chooses the dynamic min step.

Things to consider: 
It is not suggested to use this feature when creating annotations for the purpose of alerting
https://github.com/grafana/support-escalations/issues/2019#

issue.title: (#470) Localize github.com/pkg/errors
issue.body:
# Motivation
[Issue](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/issues/470) #470 reported by @skormos

# Changes
Adds new internal package `errors` with test coverage.

# Summary
Localizes following functions (and required types and methods) from [github.com/pkg/errors](https://github.com/pkg/errors) as it is no longer being maintained.
```go
New(message string) error
Wrap(err error, message string) error
```
# Related Issues
Closes #470
Helps in #462

comment.body: Reading the change I'm not really fan of the resulting API. I wonder if we could keep backward compat (when getting a wrapped error) and at the same time, auto-wrap an error when Stack is present and Err is called. This way we do not expose a new API.

issue.title: Debian: no armhf .deb file found
issue.body:
This started showing up yesterday (possibly earlier).

```
root@docker:/# apt search nextdns
Sorting... Done
Full Text Search... Done
nextdns/stable 1.37.4 armel
  NextDNS DNS/53 to DoH Proxy

root@docker:/# apt install nextdns
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree... Done
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package nextdns
```

This is inside a Docker container running Debian testing on a Raspberry Pi 

```
root@docker:/# cat /etc/os-release
PRETTY_NAME="Debian GNU/Linux bookworm/sid"
NAME="Debian GNU/Linux"
ID=debian
HOME_URL="https://www.debian.org/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://www.debian.org/support"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.debian.org/"
```

The sources are properly added

```
root@docker:/# cat /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nextdns.list
deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/nextdns.gpg] https://repo.nextdns.io/deb stable main
```

Running the install script gives the same error (nextdns not found).

It looks like searching for nextdns returns the `armel` version, but not the `armhf` version. This is also true outside of a docker container (ie on the host). 

```
liana ~ # apt search nextdns
Sorting... Done
Full Text Search... Done
nextdns/stable 1.37.4 armel
  NextDNS DNS/53 to DoH Proxy
liana ~ # uname -a
Linux liana 5.10.63-v7l+ #1459 SMP Wed Oct 6 16:41:57 BST 2021 armv7l GNU/Linux
```

issue.title: Must manually input iptables rules on UDMP (UniFi Dream Machine Pro)
issue.body:
## Context
 - CLI Version: nextdns version 1.37.11
 - IPv4 and IPv6 native (via Prefix Delegation and RA)
 - Platform:  UDM Pro
 ```
Device information summary:
    Subsystem ID: ea15
    Family: UniFi Dream Machine (UDM)
    Model: UniFi Dream Machine Pro (UDM-Pro)
    Firmware: 1.12.22 (1.12.22)
```
### Expected
Installing on UbiOS should automatically start routing DNS to NextDNS over DoH

### Actual
nextdns service was started and running, but DNS resolution was going to my ISP instead

## Debug Steps
I installed NextDNS via the UniFi [NextDNS wiki](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/UnifiOS) without any errors. Once installed, the service said it was installed and `nextdns status` showed `running` - `nextdns log` had no errors


When viewing [my.nextdns.io](https://my.nextdns.io) I noticed the status showed red and then sometimes went green as configured properly. When viewing logs, no traffic was coming through regularly, however. I verified my dns server handed out by DHCP pointed to my UDM / router. When it went red, it was showing that it was using my ISP's NS which was a little fishy since only the UDM should be using that... After reviewing the go setup code for ubi (https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/blob/master/router/ubios/setup.go#L97-L118) I saw iptables were used to reroute DNS traffic over to nextdns so I went to verify this. Surprisingly, nothing was there except the ipv4 chain... so I restarted the service, and there still were no rules. I then proceeded to create the ipv4 rules, ipv6 chain, and ipv6 rules manually over ssh. 


After setting these rules, it instantly worked on all of my devices leading me to believe there is something funky going on in the go code.

## Workaround
Manually running the following commands on the UDM / Gateway
```
iptables -t nat -N NEXTDNS
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING 1 -m addrtype --dst-type LOCAL -j NEXTDNS
iptables -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p udp -m udp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination 127.0.0.1:5553
iptables -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p tcp -m tcp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination 127.0.0.1:5553
# if using IPv6 run the following too
ip6tables -t nat -N NEXTDNS
ip6tables -t nat -I PREROUTING 1 -m set --match-set UBIOS6ADDRv6_br0 dst -j NEXTDNS
ip6tables  -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p udp -m udp --dport 53 -j REDIRECT --to-port 5553
ip6tables  -t nat -A NEXTDNS -p tcp -m tcp --dport 53 -j REDIRECT --to-port 5553
```


I also could get NextDNS resolution working if I changed the WAN DNS settings in the control panel to use the given IPs in the NextDNS setup, but this would not run through DoH. This is how I got my UniFi gear to resolve through NextDNS though, as they wouldn't happily use the gateway's proxy.

comment.body: Do you have any idea why the iptables for IPv6 are disappearing? Are they added then removed or not added at all?

issue.title: Fatal() does os.Exit(1) when log is disabled
issue.body:
I think this is an error, It was discovered after upgrading from 1.26.1 to 1.28.0:

`Fatal()` here https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L367

calls `newEvent` https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L444

 with the `done` paremeter being `os.Exit(1)` so here even the log is disabled, `done` is executed which was not like this before:

https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L448

comment.body: If you call Fatal on a logger in your code, you are not supposed to know the logger is disabled, and the code logic is not supposed to pass the Fatal statement.

issue.title: Fatal() does os.Exit(1) when log is disabled
issue.body:
I think this is an error, It was discovered after upgrading from 1.26.1 to 1.28.0:

`Fatal()` here https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L367

calls `newEvent` https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L444

 with the `done` paremeter being `os.Exit(1)` so here even the log is disabled, `done` is executed which was not like this before:

https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/d894f123bc5c2a887c95e90218b9410563141d67/log.go#L448

comment.body: This is the expected behavior though. Disabling logging should only disable the logging and not change the flow of you code.
